reviews.content: GlenDronach is a bit of a one-trick pony, but boy, they know how to make a great sherry malt! Recent batches of the 'Allardice' are much older than 18 years, and the age shows. Heavy sherry notes, oranges and rich spices bewitch the nose, intermingled with hazelnuts, roasted coffee and subdued herbal freshness. The taste is intense, full-bodied and very much in line with the aroma, culminating in a substantial, lasting and chocolaty bitter finish. Not quite as complex as the fantastic 15-year-old Revival, but who am I to criticize this superb whisky!RATING: 4.4/5.0 stars ≙ 90 pts → SUPERB [-]
color is fantastic to be natural.I like a good sweet sherry bomb, and this is a good one.Would not mind a little longer finish though.

reviews.taste: raisins, prunes, chocolate, black cherries, oak, a touch of bitter orange
reviews.finish: sweet, going dry, warming, mildly spicy

reviews.content: Beautiful whisky where the influences of the sherry barrels are clearly visible. Full smell and taste, pleasure to drink.

reviews.taste: Full, spicy. Red fruit, Chocolate, sweet. Coffee, toffee. And (oak) wood.
reviews.finish: Reasonably long, light pepper now, dry, becomes a bit bitter. Again red fruit and chocolate. And wood tones.

reviews.content: Very dark it comes into the glass, almost brown, and immediately a wonderful fruity aroma rises to my nose. Plums, overripe apples, cloves, gingerbread spice. Oh, a first drop runs me mild and oily over the tongue, but then unfolds a strong aroma, which now combines all fruits to a spicy compote. A sherry note is added, slightly vanilla, now reminds me of a Yamazaki. You can taste the age, the complexity. Great 18 year old whisky, which is still affordable and can enrich any (small) collection ...
I miss a little bit the force compared to other previously tried Glendronachs
reviews.nose: Heavy, first honey sweet with intense sherry, with longer Verriechen oak comes out, woody, fruit compote of plums, raisins and a dash of lemon, before the second sip a touch of licorice and leather, after some time more and more clear
reviews.taste: Sweet, syrupy, grapes, raisins, lots of oak, vanilla, gets spicier and less sweet from mouth to mouth
reviews.finish: Dry with a lot of oak, grape skins, medium long, becoming bitter towards the end

reviews.content: N: A potent youthful mix with a sweet-vegetal funk [Clynelish, Mortlach?], and descriptors including treacle sponge, powdered matcha, a touch of brown sauce, butter biscuits and dried confectionary candy bits. There's a lot more here when time allows.T: Softer than expected and very controlled - therefore the maturer of the bunch, with a squidgy, sweet tawny-port body seasoned with a little salt. Very delicious juice.F: Rolls on, tasty sweet-to-sour with a dash of double cream and a pinch of eucalyptus~aniseed heat-fresh. Nice dry finish, a little fruity but plenty sweet at the end and in the main.C: Overall sweet and moorish. Rather different in character to the last Allardice i tried last year [88 points], but more similar in profile to a batch i tried 4-5 years back where the sherry influence was also slight. Good stuff for sure but still a far cry from those brilliant [15yo] Revival’s.Scores a B-/85 pointsFull report HERE.

N: Aah yes, like the Revival this has that tomato/tamari quality [close comparisons were made with it and Karuizawa’s ‘Spirit of Asama’ recently] - and like the 15yo, this 18yo also has a youthfulness coupled with tasty, lickable oak.T: Balanced throughout, no surprises there coming from Glendronach and all - and with lovely sulphury huesF: Tails off appropriately. Super blending of quality stockC: With the Revival still out of commission [2016], it's this, the 12yo WB or Glendronach’s 'experiments' - yep, nearly everyone’s involved in the NAS games. The 21yo Parliament WB is still a good bet but this 18yo trumps it easily.Scores a B[+]/88 points

reviews.content: Very coppery sherry, quite dry, deep, fruity, spicy pear, rhubarb compote, fresh leather, plum, wood. Varnish and a hint of camphor. It is slightly acidic, and delicious, even pastry, sponge cake, chocolate fondant, praline. Long finish that gives on earth, licorice and charcoal. A few ground coffee beans, a pinch of pepper. Cinnamon. This aging in Oloroso sherry barrels will delight fans, for my part I find it excellent but a little too sweet. https://ilikesky2020.blogspot.com/2020/07/glendronach-18-yo-allardice.html

The oak provides but for a generally tartier character! Over time, the oak increases and the fruity side fades into the background.
reviews.taste: Full and intense with pleasant tingles. Sherry and leathery liquorice dominate, the classic oak is a bit behind. Rather dry. With the second sip comes more oak. Liquorice .... That's all in all good!
reviews.finish: The whisky stays in the mouth and throat for a long time, but not very warm.

reviews.content: S 7Very oaky given its age, it's possibly stock from 2019 or before. Very well constructed sherried whiskies but at the same time nothing surprising. The nose is great but unfortunately failed to deliver at the same level on the palate.[83-85] I'll get a bottle unless my bank account says otherwise.N 27Dark plums. Dark chocolate shaving. Medjool dates. Espresso beans. Mixed nutes. Juicy raisins. Figs. Lightly caramelised honey. A whiff of fizzy minerals.P 26Oily mouthfeel. Oaky & slightly sour at the beginning, also the alcohol was quite punchy. Old leather. Juicy dark fruits are there but much weaker than the oak. Chilli and white pepper. Fresh honey slowing surfacing from the bottom.F 23Mid, oaky finish. Old furniture. A mild touch of mixed nuts again.
Well balanced sherry dram that's also easygoing. In my pre-historic scoring method, this is an 8.7/10.

reviews.taste: If the wood now cuts through, then it tends to be in the bitter direction. Too bad. But the creamy sherry effect comes quickly. Now orange caramel in plum jam. It is full-bodied and wonderfully oily. But ... something bothers me on the bitter side. Still a good palate!
reviews.finish: Rather long and with a mouthfeel similar to cough syrup, he slowly leaves the stage. It stays wonderfully sweet. A woody, cooling menthol taste in the background. Has something. But it doesn't make it onto the shelf.  Thanks to André for the great rehearsal.

reviews.content: A classy, bitter dram.Even as someone who doesn't usually enjoy dry whiskies, I was captivated by this one.It has the rich, sweet character of a 21-year-old, but the sophisticated bitterness of the 18-year-old makes it hard to choose between the two. Both are excellent in their own way.
reviews.nose: Nosing: Rose Incense, Dark Chocolate, Biscuit, Raisin, Cacao The aroma is calm and refined, reminiscent of Glenfarclas' first-fill sherry cask.It feels like the elegant, old-fashioned oloroso sherry note is packed tightly into a single glass.From the scent alone, you can sense it's going to be dry.
reviews.taste: Palate: Dark Chocolate, Dried Fig, Fig Jam, Tobacco, Spicy Despite the sweetness being quite restrained, it somehow activates your salivary glands.There are nuances of dried figs and fig jam, but paradoxically, it feels like there’s no sugar.There's also a subtle tobacco flavor, along with a notable spiciness that seems to come from European oak.
reviews.finish: Finish: Woody, Dark Chocolate, Cacao, Espresso It's impressive how they managed to draw out such bitterness while holding back the sweetness.Although I usually prefer sweetness, I can't help but praise this finish. It's a refined, pleasant bitterness taken to the extreme.The lingering woody and dark chocolate bitterness stays for a long time, feeling like cacao or espresso, making for a very enjoyable finish.
